name: African Elephant
fun_facts: African elephants are the largest land animals.
They use their trunks for breathing, smelling, touching, grasping, and producing sound.
Elephants are highly intelligent and have complex social structures.
habitat: Savannas, grasslands, and forests across sub-Saharan Africa.
diet: Herbivore (grasses, leaves, bark, roots, fruits)
interesting_fact: Elephants affect their environment perhaps more than any other creature on earth; their feeding habits can significantly change landscapes.

name: Bald Eagle
fun_facts: Despite its name, the Bald Eagle isn't actually bald; its name comes from an older meaning of 'white-headed'.
They build the largest nests of any North American bird, often weighing over a ton.
Their eyesight is 3-4 times better than a human's.
habitat: Near large bodies of open water with abundant food supply and old-growth trees for nesting, across North America.
diet: Carnivore (mainly fish, but also small birds, mammals, reptiles, crabs, amphibians)
average_lifespan_years: 20-30 in the wild, up to 36 in captivity
interesting_fact: The Bald Eagle has been the national bird of the United States of America since 1782.

name: Bengal Tiger
fun_facts: Bengal tigers are solitary hunters and excellent swimmers.
Their stripes are unique to each individual, like human fingerprints.
They can roar to signal their presence to other tigers up to 3 km away.
habitat: Tropical moist evergreen forests, dry forests, mangroves, and grasslands in India, Bangladesh, Nepal, and Bhutan.
diet: Carnivore (large ungulates like gaur, sambar, chital, wild boar)
average_lifespan_years: 10-15 in the wild, up to 20 in captivity
interesting_fact: Tigers in the Sundarbans mangrove forests of India and Bangladesh are the only ones in the world inhabiting such an environment.

name: Blue Whale
fun_facts: The blue whale is the largest animal on Earth, weighing as much as 30 elephants.
Its tongue alone can weigh as much as an elephant.
Despite its massive size, it feeds almost exclusively on tiny krill.
habitat: All oceans, migrating between feeding grounds in polar waters and breeding grounds in warmer, tropical waters.
diet: Carnivore (almost exclusively krill)
predators: Orcas (killer whales, though rare for healthy adults)
interesting_fact: A blue whale's heart is the size of a small car, and its main artery is large enough for a human to crawl through.

name: Cheetah
fun_facts: Cheetahs are the fastest land animals, capable of reaching speeds up to 112 km/h (70 mph).
Their non-retractable claws act like running spikes for extra grip.
The black 'tear marks' running from their eyes help reduce sun glare during hunts.
habitat: Savannas, grasslands, and open woodlands in Africa and a small population in Iran.
diet: Carnivore (gazelles, impalas, wildebeest calves, hares, birds)
average_lifespan_years: 10-12 in the wild
interesting_fact: Unlike other big cats, cheetahs don't roar; they purr, chirp, and hiss.

name: Chimpanzee
fun_facts: Chimpanzees are one of humans' closest living relatives, sharing about 98% of our DNA.
They are highly intelligent and use tools, solve problems, and exhibit complex social behaviors.
Chimps communicate through a variety of vocalizations, gestures, and facial expressions.
habitat: Tropical forests and savannas of equatorial Africa.
diet: Omnivore (mainly fruits, leaves, insects, but also small mammals like monkeys)
average_lifespan_years: 40-50 in the wild, up to 60 in captivity
interesting_fact: Chimpanzees are known to engage in cooperative hunting, often targeting other primates.

name: Clownfish
fun_facts: Clownfish live in a symbiotic relationship with sea anemones, being immune to their stinging tentacles.
They are all born male and can change to female later in life if the dominant female of a group dies.
Their bright colors make them easily recognizable.
habitat: Coral reefs in the Indian and Pacific Oceans.
diet: Omnivore (small invertebrates, algae, zooplankton, uneaten food from the anemone)
predators: Larger fish (e.g., sharks, groupers, moray eels)
average_lifespan_years: 6-10 in the wild, up to 18 in aquariums
interesting_fact: The mucus coating on a clownfish's skin is believed to be the secret to its immunity to anemone stings.

name: Crocodile
fun_facts: Crocodiles have one of the strongest bite forces in the animal kingdom.
They have excellent night vision and are primarily nocturnal hunters.
Crocodiles have a four-chambered heart, similar to mammals and birds.
habitat: Freshwater habitats such as rivers, lakes, and wetlands, and sometimes brackish or saltwater, across tropical regions worldwide.
diet: Carnivore (fish, reptiles, birds, mammals)
average_lifespan_years: 30-70, some species up to 100
interesting_fact: Crocodiles do not have sweat glands and release heat through their mouths, often sleeping with their mouths open.

name: Dolphin
fun_facts: Dolphins are highly intelligent marine mammals known for their playful behavior.
They use echolocation (sonar) to navigate and hunt, emitting high-frequency clicks.
Dolphins can communicate with each other through a variety of whistles and clicks.
habitat: Oceans worldwide, from coastal waters to the open sea.
diet: Carnivore (fish and squid)
average_lifespan_years: 20-50 depending on species
interesting_fact: Some dolphin species, like bottlenose dolphins, have unique 'signature whistles' that act like names for individual dolphins.

name: Giant Panda
fun_facts: Giant Pandas are known for their distinctive black and white fur, which provides camouflage in snowy, rocky habitats.
Despite being classified as carnivores, their diet is 99% bamboo.
They spend at least 12-15 hours a day eating bamboo.
habitat: Mountainous regions with dense bamboo forests in central China.
diet: Herbivore (almost exclusively bamboo)
average_lifespan_years: 14-20 in the wild, up to 30 in captivity
interesting_fact: Giant pandas have an extra 'thumb' (a modified wrist bone) that helps them grip bamboo stalks.

name: Giraffe
fun_facts: Giraffes are the tallest mammals on Earth, with males reaching up to 5.5 meters (18 feet) tall.
Their long necks contain the same number of vertebrae as a human neck (seven), but each is much larger.
No two giraffes have the same spot pattern.
habitat: Savannas, grasslands, and open woodlands in Africa.
diet: Herbivore (leaves, flowers, fruits, especially acacia leaves)
average_lifespan_years: 20-25 in the wild, up to 30 in captivity
interesting_fact: Giraffes only need 5 to 30 minutes of sleep in a 24-hour period, often taking short naps while standing.

name: Grizzly Bear
fun_facts: Grizzly bears are a subspecies of brown bear, known for the grizzled (gray-tipped) fur on their backs.
They have a distinctive shoulder hump, which is a muscle mass used for digging.
Despite their size, grizzlies can run at speeds of up to 56 km/h (35 mph).
habitat: Forests, mountains, and open tundra in western North America.
diet: Omnivore (berries, roots, nuts, fish, small mammals, carrion)
average_lifespan_years: 20-25 in the wild, up to 30 in captivity
interesting_fact: Grizzly bears are incredibly solitary animals, except when females are raising cubs.

name: Hippopotamus
fun_facts: Hippos spend up to 16 hours a day in water to keep their skin cool and moist.
Despite their bulky appearance, they are surprisingly agile in water and can hold their breath for up to 5 minutes.
Their skin secretes a red, oily substance that acts as a natural sunscreen and moisturizer.
habitat: Rivers, lakes, and mangrove swamps in sub-Saharan Africa.
diet: Herbivore (primarily short grasses found on land)
predators: Lions (prey on young hippos or isolated adults)
average_lifespan_years: 40-50 in the wild, up to 60 in captivity
interesting_fact: Hippos are responsible for more human fatalities in Africa than any other large animal, due to their aggressive and territorial nature.

name: Horse
fun_facts: Horses can sleep both standing up and lying down.
Their eyes are on the sides of their heads, giving them nearly 360-degree vision.
Horses communicate through a variety of whinnies, neighs, and body language.
habitat: Domesticated worldwide; wild horses (like Przewalski's horse) inhabit grasslands and steppes.
diet: Herbivore (grasses, hay, grains)
average_lifespan_years: 25-30, some live into their 40s
interesting_fact: Horses are social animals and will become lonely if kept without the companionship of other horses or animals.

name: Kangaroo
fun_facts: Kangaroos are marsupials, and females carry their young (joeys) in a pouch.
They use their strong hind legs for hopping, which is an energy-efficient way to travel.
Kangaroos are the only large animals to use hopping as their primary means of locomotion.
habitat: Various habitats across Australia, including forests, woodlands, savannas, and grasslands.
diet: Herbivore (grasses, leaves, flowers)
average_lifespan_years: 6-8 in the wild, up to 20 in captivity
interesting_fact: Kangaroos cannot walk backward due to the shape of their legs and tails.

name: Koala
fun_facts: Koalas are marsupials native to Australia, known for their fluffy ears and large noses.
They have fingerprints almost identical to human fingerprints.
Koalas sleep up to 20 hours a day, largely due to their low-energy diet of eucalyptus leaves.
habitat: Eucalyptus forests and woodlands in eastern and southeastern Australia.
diet: Herbivore (almost exclusively eucalyptus leaves)
average_lifespan_years: 13-18 in the wild, up to 20 in captivity
interesting_fact: Koalas have a specialized digestive system to detoxify the poisonous compounds in eucalyptus leaves.

name: Leopard
fun_facts: Leopards are known for their distinctive rosette-patterned coats, which provide excellent camouflage.
They are incredibly adaptable and can be found in a wide range of habitats.
Leopards are solitary and largely nocturnal hunters, often dragging their kills up trees to protect them from other predators.
habitat: Wide range, including forests, savannas, mountains, and grasslands across Africa and parts of Asia.
diet: Carnivore (deer, antelopes, warthogs, primates, rodents, reptiles, birds)
average_lifespan_years: 12-17 in the wild, up to 21 in captivity
interesting_fact: Leopards are strong climbers and can often be seen resting in trees during the day.

name: Lion
fun_facts: Lions are the only cats that live in groups, called prides, which can consist of up to 40 individuals.
A lion's roar can be heard up to 8 kilometers (5 miles) away.
Females do most of the hunting for the pride.
habitat: Savannas, grasslands, and open woodlands in sub-Saharan Africa and a small population in India (Gir Forest).
diet: Carnivore (large ungulates like wildebeest, zebra, buffalo, giraffe)
average_lifespan_years: 10-14 in the wild, up to 20 in captivity
interesting_fact: Male lions are easily recognizable by their magnificent manes, which signal their health and virility and also protect their neck during fights.

name: Lynx
fun_facts: Lynx are medium-sized wild cats with distinctive tufted ears and short tails.
Their large, padded paws act like snowshoes, helping them move silently over snow.
Lynx are solitary and primarily nocturnal hunters.
habitat: Boreal forests across North America, Europe, and Asia.
diet: Carnivore (snowshoe hares are a primary food source, but also deer, rodents, birds)
average_lifespan_years: 10-15 in the wild
interesting_fact: The population of Canadian lynx closely follows the population cycle of their main prey, the snowshoe hare.

name: Manatee
fun_facts: Manatees are large, slow-moving marine mammals often called 'sea cows'.
They are herbivores and spend most of their time grazing on seagrass and other aquatic vegetation.
Manatees have powerful tails that propel them through water and two flippers used for steering and balance.
habitat: Shallow, slow-moving rivers, estuaries, saltwater bays, canals, and coastal areas in warm waters (Florida, Caribbean, Amazon Basin, West Africa).
diet: Herbivore (seagrass, aquatic plants)
interesting_fact: Manatees have very few natural predators, but their slow movement and coastal habitat make them vulnerable to human activities.

name: Meerkat
fun_facts: Meerkats are small mongooses known for their upright sentry duty, watching for predators.
They live in highly social groups called mobs or gangs, ranging from 3 to 50 individuals.
Each meerkat has a specific role within the group, including foraging, babysitting, and standing guard.
habitat: Arid and semi-arid grasslands, savannas, and open plains in Southern Africa (Kalahari Desert).
diet: Omnivore (mainly insects, but also lizards, snakes, scorpions, eggs, small mammals, roots, and tubers)
average_lifespan_years: 6-10 in the wild, up to 12-14 in captivity
interesting_fact: Meerkats are immune to the venom of certain scorpions and snakes found in their habitat.

name: Moose
fun_facts: Moose are the largest members of the deer family, easily recognized by the broad, palmate antlers of the males.
They are excellent swimmers and can dive for aquatic plants.
A moose's nose is highly sensitive to smell and helps them locate food under snow or in water.
habitat: Boreal forests and temperate broadleaf and mixed forests in North America, Europe, and Asia.
diet: Herbivore (twigs, bark, leaves of trees and shrubs, aquatic vegetation)
prey: Leaves of trees and shrubs (e.g., willow, birch, aspen)
average_lifespan_years: 15-20 in the wild
interesting_fact: The term 'moose' is derived from the Algonquian word meaning 'eater of twigs'.

name: Mountain Gorilla
fun_facts: Mountain gorillas are one of the two subspecies of eastern gorillas and are critically endangered.
They live in highly cohesive family groups led by a dominant silverback male.
Each gorilla has unique nose prints, similar to human fingerprints.
habitat: Cloud forests in the Virunga volcanic mountains of Central Africa (Rwanda, Uganda, Democratic Republic of Congo).
diet: Herbivore (leaves, stems, roots, flowers, bark, some fruit, small insects)
interesting_fact: Mountain gorillas are known for their gentle and shy nature despite their intimidating size.

name: Narwhal
fun_facts: Narwhals are often called the 'unicorns of the sea' due to the male's distinctive long, spiraled tusk.
The tusk is an elongated canine tooth that can grow up to 3 meters (10 feet) long.
They are deep divers, capable of diving to depths of 1,500 meters (4,900 feet).
habitat: Arctic waters of Canada, Greenland, Norway, and Russia.
diet: Carnivore (Greenland halibut, polar cod, shrimp, squid)
interesting_fact: The narwhal's tusk is a sensory organ with up to 10 million nerve endings, used for navigating, foraging, and possibly communicating.

name: Orangutan
fun_facts: Orangutans are the largest tree-dwelling animals in the world.
Their name means 'person of the forest' in Malay.
They have long, reddish-brown hair and incredibly long arms, which can span over 2 meters (7 feet).
habitat: Tropical rainforests on the islands of Borneo and Sumatra in Southeast Asia.
diet: Herbivore (primarily fruits, but also leaves, bark, honey, insects, bird eggs)
average_lifespan_years: 30-40 in the wild, up to 50 in captivity
interesting_fact: Orangutans are known for their intelligence and ability to use tools and build complex nests for sleeping.

name: Ostrich
fun_facts: Ostriches are the largest and heaviest living birds, though they cannot fly.
They can run at speeds of up to 70 km/h (43 mph), making them the fastest birds on land.
An ostrich's eye is the largest of any land animal, measuring almost 5 cm (2 inches) in diameter.
habitat: Savannas and semi-arid plains of Africa.
diet: Herbivore (grasses, flowers, seeds, leaves, occasionally insects and small reptiles)
interesting_fact: Ostrich eggs are the largest of any bird, weighing around 1.4 kg (3 pounds).

name: Otter
fun_facts: Otters are semi-aquatic carnivorous mammals known for their playful behavior.
They often hold hands while sleeping to avoid drifting apart in the water.
Otters use rocks as tools to crack open shellfish.
habitat: Rivers, lakes, coastlines, and wetlands worldwide, depending on the species.
diet: Carnivore (fish, crustaceans, frogs, small mammals, birds)
average_lifespan_years: 10-15 in the wild, up to 20 in captivity
interesting_fact: Sea otters are unique in that they don't have blubber like other marine mammals, relying instead on incredibly dense fur for insulation.

name: Owl
fun_facts: Owls are nocturnal birds of prey known for their silent flight and excellent night vision.
They can rotate their heads up to 270 degrees in either direction.
Most owls hunt by sound, using their asymmetrical ears to pinpoint prey.
habitat: Forests, deserts, mountains, and grasslands across the globe, excluding Antarctica.
diet: Carnivore (rodents, insects, birds, small mammals, fish)
average_lifespan_years: 5-30 depending on species
interesting_fact: Owl feathers are specially adapted with serrated edges and a soft, velvety surface to reduce turbulence and make their flight virtually silent.

name: Penguin
fun_facts: Penguins are flightless birds highly adapted for life in the water.
They are excellent swimmers and divers, using their wings as flippers.
Most penguin species live in the Southern Hemisphere, with only one species (Galapagos penguin) living north of the equator.
habitat: Coastal regions and open ocean of the Southern Hemisphere, from Antarctica to the Gal√°pagos Islands.
diet: Carnivore (fish, krill, squid)
average_lifespan_years: 15-20 in the wild, some species longer
interesting_fact: Penguins have a countercurrent heat exchange system in their flippers and legs to minimize heat loss in cold water.

name: Polar Bear
fun_facts: Polar bears are the largest land predators and are exceptionally well-adapted to Arctic environments.
Their fur is not white, but translucent, hollow tubes that reflect light, making them appear white.
They have an excellent sense of smell, capable of detecting seals up to 30 km (18 miles) away.
habitat: Arctic regions around the North Pole, primarily on sea ice.
diet: Carnivore (mainly seals, but also walruses, whales, birds, eggs)
average_lifespan_years: 15-18 in the wild, up to 30 in captivity
interesting_fact: Polar bears are considered marine mammals because they spend most of their lives on sea ice and in the ocean.

name: Porcupine
fun_facts: Porcupines are rodents known for their coat of sharp quills, which serve as a defense mechanism.
They cannot 'shoot' their quills, but the quills are loosely attached and can detach easily upon contact.
A porcupine typically has around 30,000 quills.
habitat: Forests, grasslands, deserts, and mountains across North America, Africa, Asia, and Europe.
diet: Herbivore (bark, leaves, roots, stems, buds, fruits, sometimes small insects or carrion)
average_lifespan_years: 5-10 in the wild, up to 15 in captivity
interesting_fact: New World porcupines are excellent climbers, using their prehensile tails to grip branches.

name: Raccoon
fun_facts: Raccoons are known for their distinctive 'bandit mask' around their eyes and bushy, ringed tails.
They are highly intelligent and adaptable, thriving in various environments, including urban areas.
Raccoons have extremely dexterous front paws, which they use to manipulate objects and 'wash' their food.
habitat: Forests, wetlands, urban areas across North America, and parts of Europe and Asia (introduced).
diet: Omnivore (fruits, nuts, insects, rodents, frogs, fish, eggs, carrion, human refuse)
average_lifespan_years: 2-3 in the wild, up to 20 in captivity
interesting_fact: The 'washing' behavior of raccoons is thought to enhance their sense of touch, as their paw pads become more sensitive when wet.

name: Red Fox
fun_facts: Red foxes are the largest of the true foxes and the most widely distributed carnivorous mammals.
They have excellent hearing, capable of hearing low-frequency sounds and prey digging underground.
Red foxes are solitary hunters but often live in family groups during breeding season.
habitat: Forests, grasslands, mountains, deserts, and urban areas across the Northern Hemisphere.
diet: Omnivore (rodents, rabbits, birds, insects, fruits, berries, carrion)
average_lifespan_years: 2-5 in the wild, up to 10 in captivity
interesting_fact: Red foxes use a unique hunting technique called 'mousing' where they leap high into the air and pounce on hidden prey.

name: Red Panda
fun_facts: Red pandas are often called 'lesser pandas' and are not closely related to giant pandas.
They have a false thumb, which is an extension of the wrist bone, helping them grip bamboo.
Red pandas are excellent climbers and spend most of their lives in trees.
habitat: Temperate forests in the Himalayas of Nepal, India, Bhutan, China, and Myanmar.
diet: Herbivore (primarily bamboo, but also fruits, acorns, roots, eggs, small birds, insects)
average_lifespan_years: 8-10 in the wild, up to 15 in captivity
interesting_fact: Red pandas are crepuscular, meaning they are most active during dawn and dusk.

name: Reindeer
fun_facts: Reindeer (or caribou in North America) are the only deer species where both males and females grow antlers.
Their hooves adapt to seasons, shrinking in winter to expose the rim for better grip on ice and snow.
Reindeer migrate further than any other land mammal, covering thousands of kilometers annually.
habitat: Tundra, boreal forests, and mountains in Arctic and sub-Arctic regions of North America, Europe, and Asia.
diet: Herbivore (lichen, mosses, herbs, ferns, grasses, leaves of shrubs and trees)
average_lifespan_years: 15-20 in the wild
interesting_fact: Reindeer have a specialized nose that warms cold air before it enters their lungs and extracts moisture from their breath, preventing heat and water loss.

name: Rhino
fun_facts: Rhinoceroses are large, herbivorous mammals distinguished by their large horn or horns.
Their name comes from the Greek words 'rhino' (nose) and 'ceros' (horn).
Rhinos have poor eyesight but excellent senses of smell and hearing.
habitat: Grasslands, savannas, tropical and subtropical forests in Africa and Asia.
diet: Herbivore (grasses, leaves, shoots, bark, fruits)
predators: Lions (occasionally target calves or weak adults)
interesting_fact: The 'horn' of a rhino is made of keratin, the same protein that makes up human hair and fingernails, not bone.

name: Sea Lion
fun_facts: Sea lions are pinnipeds characterized by external ear flaps, long front flippers, and the ability to walk on all four flippers.
They are highly social animals, often seen in large colonies on coastlines and islands.
Sea lions are agile swimmers and can reach speeds of up to 30 km/h (18 mph) in water.
habitat: Coastal waters and islands of temperate and tropical regions worldwide, except the North Atlantic.
diet: Carnivore (fish, squid, octopus, crustaceans)
interesting_fact: California sea lions are often used in marine mammal shows due to their intelligence and trainability.

name: Sea Turtle
fun_facts: Sea turtles are ancient reptiles that have existed for over 100 million years.
They cannot retract their heads or limbs into their shells like land turtles.
Females return to the same beaches where they were born to lay their eggs.
habitat: Tropical and subtropical oceans worldwide, with specific species preferring different habitats (e.g., coral reefs, seagrass beds, open ocean).
diet: Omnivore (depending on species: jellyfish, algae, seagrass, crustaceans, mollusks)
interesting_fact: The leatherback sea turtle is the largest sea turtle and can dive deeper than any other reptile, reaching depths of over 1,200 meters (4,000 feet).

name: Seal
fun_facts: Seals are marine mammals known for their sleek, torpedo-shaped bodies and flippers.
Unlike sea lions, true seals lack external ear flaps and cannot rotate their hind flippers forward, making them less agile on land.
They spend most of their lives in the water and are excellent divers.
habitat: Coastal waters, ice floes, and open ocean in polar, temperate, and some tropical regions worldwide.
diet: Carnivore (fish, squid, crustaceans)
interesting_fact: Weddell seals can stay underwater for over 80 minutes, holding their breath longer than any other diving mammal.

name: Shark
fun_facts: Sharks are a group of cartilaginous fish with skeletons made of cartilage instead of bone.
They have multiple rows of teeth that are constantly replaced throughout their lives.
Sharks have an exceptional sense of smell and can detect a single drop of blood in a vast amount of water.
habitat: All oceans worldwide, from shallow coastal waters to the deep sea.
diet: Carnivore (fish, seals, sea lions, dolphins, other sharks, depending on species)
average_lifespan_years: 20-70, some species over 100
interesting_fact: The Greenland shark has the longest known lifespan of all vertebrates, estimated to live for up to 500 years.

name: Sheep
fun_facts: Sheep are ruminant mammals typically kept as livestock for their wool, meat, and milk.
They have excellent peripheral vision, with rectangular pupils that give them a wide field of view.
Sheep are known for their strong flocking instinct, providing safety in numbers.
habitat: Domesticated worldwide; wild sheep (like bighorn sheep) inhabit mountainous regions.
diet: Herbivore (grasses, clover, weeds)
interesting_fact: There are over 1,000 different breeds of sheep worldwide.

name: Sloth
fun_facts: Sloths are known for being incredibly slow, moving at a maximum speed of 0.24 km/h (0.15 mph).
Their fur often grows algae, which provides camouflage and is sometimes eaten by the sloth.
Sloths spend almost their entire lives hanging upside down in trees.
habitat: Tropical and subtropical forests of Central and South America.
diet: Herbivore (leaves, twigs, buds, some fruits)
average_lifespan_years: 20-30 in the wild
interesting_fact: Sloths only descend from trees about once a week to defecate, making them vulnerable to predators during this time.

name: Snow Leopard
fun_facts: Snow leopards are apex predators native to the mountain ranges of Central and South Asia.
They have long, thick fur and a bushy tail, which they wrap around themselves for warmth.
Their large paws act like snowshoes, distributing their weight and aiding traction on snow.
habitat: Rocky, mountainous terrain and alpine grasslands in Central and South Asia.
diet: Carnivore (wild sheep and goats, marmots, pikas, birds)
average_lifespan_years: 15-18 in the wild, up to 22 in captivity
interesting_fact: Snow leopards cannot roar like other big cats; they communicate through chuffing, purring, and other vocalizations.

name: Squid
fun_facts: Squid are cephalopods, a group of marine mollusks characterized by a distinct head, bilateral symmetry, and a set of arms or tentacles.
They have three hearts: two pump blood through the gills, and one circulates blood to the rest of the body.
Squid can change color rapidly for camouflage or communication.
habitat: All oceans, from shallow coastal waters to the deep sea.
diet: Carnivore (fish, crustaceans, other squid)
average_lifespan_years: 1-5, depending on species
interesting_fact: The giant squid has the largest eyes of any animal on Earth, up to 27 cm (11 inches) in diameter.

name: Squirrel
fun_facts: Squirrels are small to medium-sized rodents known for their bushy tails.
They are highly adaptable and can be found in various habitats, from forests to urban parks.
Squirrels are famous for burying nuts and seeds, often forgetting where they hid them, which aids in tree dispersal.
habitat: Forests, woodlands, and urban areas worldwide, excluding Australia and Antarctica.
diet: Omnivore (nuts, seeds, fruits, fungi, insects, bird eggs, young birds)
average_lifespan_years: 2-5 in the wild, up to 10 in captivity
interesting_fact: Squirrels can often climb down trees headfirst by rotating their ankles 180 degrees.

name: Tiger
fun_facts: Tigers are the largest cat species, instantly recognizable by their dark vertical stripes on reddish-orange fur.
No two tigers have the exact same stripe pattern.
They are solitary hunters and excellent swimmers.
habitat: Diverse habitats including grasslands, savannas, and forests in Asia.
diet: Carnivore (deer, wild boar, buffalo, antelope)
average_lifespan_years: 10-15 in the wild, up to 20 in captivity
interesting_fact: Tigers are powerful apex predators, playing a crucial role in maintaining the balance of ecosystems they inhabit.

name: Toad
fun_facts: Toads are amphibians known for their dry, warty skin, unlike frogs which generally have smooth, moist skin.
Many species of toads have prominent parotoid glands behind their eyes that secrete toxins to deter predators.
Toads typically walk or crawl rather than hop long distances like many frogs.
habitat: Wide range of habitats including forests, grasslands, deserts, and suburban gardens, often near water.
diet: Carnivore (insects, slugs, worms, spiders)
average_lifespan_years: 5-10 in the wild, up to 30 in captivity for some species
interesting_fact: The Colorado River Toad (Sonoran Desert Toad) is one of the largest toads found in North America and produces powerful hallucinogenic toxins.

name: Tortoise
fun_facts: Tortoises are land-dwelling reptiles, distinct from turtles by their dome-shaped shells and sturdy, club-like legs.
They are among the longest-living vertebrates, with some species living over 150 years.
Tortoises are primarily herbivorous, relying on plant matter for their diet.
habitat: Wide range, from deserts and grasslands to forests, across various continents.
diet: Herbivore (grasses, leaves, flowers, fruits)
predators: Large birds of prey (prey on young)
average_lifespan_years: 50-100+, some species over 150
interesting_fact: The Gal√°pagos tortoise is one of the most famous long-lived tortoise species, playing a significant role in Darwin's theory of evolution.

name: Tuna
fun_facts: Tuna are powerful, streamlined fish built for speed, capable of swimming at speeds up to 75 km/h (47 mph).
They are unique among fish in their ability to maintain a body temperature higher than the surrounding water.
Tuna undertake extensive migrations across oceans.
habitat: Open ocean waters worldwide, both temperate and tropical.
diet: Carnivore (fish, crustaceans, squid)
average_lifespan_years: 10-20, depending on species
interesting_fact: Bluefin tuna are among the most sought-after fish for sushi and sashimi, leading to concerns about overfishing.

name: Walrus
fun_facts: Walruses are large marine mammals known for their prominent tusks, which are elongated canine teeth.
They use their tusks to haul themselves out of the water onto ice, and to break through ice.
Walruses have sensitive whiskers (vibrissae) that help them locate food on the seabed.
habitat: Shallow coastal waters and ice floes in the Arctic Ocean and subarctic seas.
diet: Carnivore (primarily mollusks like clams, but also worms, snails, sea cucumbers, and occasionally seals)
predators: Polar bears (mainly calves or sick adults)
interesting_fact: Walruses can slow their heart rate to dive to depths of 80 meters (260 feet) or more.

name: Warthog
fun_facts: Warthogs are wild pigs found in Africa, known for their large tusks and facial warts (which are actually protective pads).
They often kneel on their front legs to graze, especially when the grass is short.
Warthogs run with their tails held straight up in the air, a peculiar and easily recognizable sight.
habitat: Grasslands, savannas, and woodlands in sub-Saharan Africa.
diet: Omnivore (grasses, roots, berries, bark, fungi, insects, eggs, carrion)
average_lifespan_years: 10-15 in the wild, up to 20 in captivity
interesting_fact: Warthogs are known to use abandoned aardvark burrows as shelter from predators and the heat, often backing in headfirst.

name: Wildebeest
fun_facts: Wildebeest, also known as gnus, are antelopes native to the savannas of Africa.
They are famous for their large annual migrations in East Africa, involving millions of animals.
Wildebeest communicate through various vocalizations, including their characteristic 'gnu' call.
habitat: Grasslands and savannas of East and Southern Africa.
diet: Herbivore (primarily short grasses)
average_lifespan_years: 15-20 in the wild
interesting_fact: During their migration, wildebeest form massive herds, which is a defense mechanism against predators, as safety lies in numbers.

name: Wolf
fun_facts: Wolves are the largest wild members of the dog family, known for their howling.
They are highly social animals, living and hunting in well-organized packs.
Wolf packs typically consist of a breeding pair, their offspring, and sometimes other non-breeding adults.
habitat: Forests, tundras, mountains, and grasslands across North America, Europe, and Asia.
diet: Carnivore (large ungulates like deer, moose, elk, caribou, and smaller prey)
average_lifespan_years: 6-8 in the wild, up to 16 in captivity
interesting_fact: Wolf howls are used for various reasons, including locating pack members, warning off rivals, and gathering the pack for a hunt.

name: Wombat
fun_facts: Wombats are marsupials native to Australia, known for their muscular, short-legged bodies and burrowing habits.
They have a unique backward-facing pouch, which prevents dirt from getting on their young while digging.
Wombats have a thick hide and a bony plate on their rump, which they use to block burrow entrances from predators.
habitat: Forests, mountains, and grasslands in southeastern Australia and Tasmania.
diet: Herbivore (grasses, roots, herbs, bark)
average_lifespan_years: 5-15 in the wild, up to 20 in captivity
interesting_fact: Wombat feces are cube-shaped, which helps them mark territory without the droppings rolling away.

name: Woodpecker
fun_facts: Woodpeckers are birds known for their ability to 'peck' holes in tree trunks, primarily to find insects.
Their skulls have specialized shock-absorbing tissues that protect their brains from repeated impacts.
They have long, barbed tongues that can extend far beyond their beaks to extract insects from wood.
habitat: Forests, woodlands, and suburban areas with trees worldwide, excluding Australia, New Zealand, and Antarctica.
diet: Omnivore (insects, larvae, sap, nuts, seeds, fruits)
average_lifespan_years: 4-12 depending on species
interesting_fact: Some woodpecker species, like sapsuckers, drill rows of small holes in trees to create wells from which they drink sap and eat insects attracted to it.

name: Zebra
fun_facts: Zebras are African equids known for their distinctive black and white striped coats.
Each zebra's stripe pattern is unique, like a human fingerprint.
The stripes are thought to deter biting flies and confuse predators.
habitat: Grasslands, savannas, and woodlands of Eastern and Southern Africa.
diet: Herbivore (primarily grasses)
average_lifespan_years: 20-30 in the wild
interesting_fact: When zebras graze in a herd, their stripes make it difficult for predators to pick out an individual, creating a 'dazzle camouflage' effect.

name: Ant
fun_facts: Ants are social insects that live in highly organized colonies.
They are incredibly strong for their size, capable of carrying objects many times their own weight.
Ants use chemical signals (pheromones) to communicate, navigate, and mark trails.
habitat: Almost all terrestrial environments worldwide, from forests and deserts to urban areas.
diet: Omnivore (nectar, seeds, fungi, insects, small animals, human food scraps)
average_lifespan_years: Weeks for workers, years for queens
interesting_fact: A single ant colony can contain millions of individual ants.

name: Armadillo
fun_facts: Armadillos are mammals known for their leathery, armor-like shell, which is made of bony plates.
The nine-banded armadillo is the only species found in the United States and can jump straight up to 3-4 feet when startled.
They are excellent diggers, using their strong claws to create burrows and forage for food.
habitat: Forests, grasslands, and semi-deserts in North, Central, and South America.
diet: Omnivore (insects, larvae, worms, roots, fruits, sometimes small vertebrates)
average_lifespan_years: 4-7 in the wild, up to 20 in captivity
interesting_fact: Armadillos can hold their breath for up to 6 minutes, allowing them to cross small bodies of water underwater by walking on the bottom.

name: Bat
fun_facts: Bats are the only mammals capable of sustained flight.
Most bats are nocturnal and use echolocation to navigate and hunt in the dark.
There are over 1,400 species of bats, making them the second most diverse order of mammals after rodents.
habitat: Forests, caves, wetlands, deserts, and urban areas worldwide, excluding Antarctica and some oceanic islands.
diet: Varies by species (insects, fruits, nectar, pollen, fish, small animals, blood for vampire bats)
average_lifespan_years: 5-30, depending on species
interesting_fact: Many bat species play vital roles in ecosystems by pollinating plants and dispersing seeds.

name: Beaver
fun_facts: Beavers are the second-largest rodents in the world, known for their ability to build dams and lodges.
They have large, constantly growing incisors that they use to gnaw down trees.
Their broad, flat, scaly tail is used for steering in water, storing fat, and signaling danger by slapping it on the water.
habitat: Rivers, streams, lakes, and ponds in temperate North America and Eurasia.
diet: Herbivore (bark, leaves, twigs, roots of trees and aquatic plants)
prey: Roots of trees (especially aspen, willow, birch)
average_lifespan_years: 10-15 in the wild, up to 20 in captivity
interesting_fact: Beaver dams create wetlands that support a wide variety of other wildlife.

name: Bee
fun_facts: Bees are flying insects known for their role in pollination and, in the case of honey bees, for producing honey and beeswax.
They live in highly organized colonies with a queen, drones, and worker bees.
Honey bees perform a 'waggle dance' to communicate the location of food sources to other bees.
habitat: Found in almost every habitat containing flowering plants, globally.
diet: Herbivore (nectar and pollen from flowers)
average_lifespan_years: Few weeks for worker bees, 1-5 years for queen bees
interesting_fact: A single honey bee visits 50 to 100 flowers during a collection trip.

name: Bison
fun_facts: Bison are large, shaggy-haired bovines native to North America and Europe (European bison or wisent).
They are the largest land animals in North America.
Bison play a crucial role in grassland ecosystems through their grazing and trampling, which helps maintain biodiversity.
habitat: Grasslands, plains, and open woodlands in North America and parts of Europe.
diet: Herbivore (primarily grasses and sedges)
average_lifespan_years: 15-20 in the wild, up to 25 in captivity
interesting_fact: Despite their massive size, bison are surprisingly agile and can run up to 56 km/h (35 mph) and jump over 1.8 meters (6 feet) high.

name: Butterfly
fun_facts: Butterflies undergo complete metamorphosis, transforming from a larva (caterpillar) to a pupa, and then to an adult butterfly.
Their wings are covered in tiny, overlapping scales that create their vibrant colors and patterns.
Butterflies taste with their feet and feed using a proboscis, a long, tube-like mouthpart.
habitat: Diverse habitats worldwide, including forests, grasslands, deserts, wetlands, and urban gardens.
diet: Herbivore (nectar, sap, rotting fruit, dung, pollen)
average_lifespan_years: Few weeks to several months (some migratory species can live up to 9 months)
interesting_fact: The monarch butterfly undertakes an incredible annual migration of up to 4,800 kilometers (3,000 miles) from Canada and the US to Mexico.

name: Camel
fun_facts: Camels are even-toed ungulates known for their distinctive fatty humps (one for dromedaries, two for Bactrian camels).
The humps store fat, which can be metabolized for energy and water, allowing them to survive long periods without food or water.
Camels can close their nostrils to keep sand out and have long eyelashes to protect their eyes from sandstorms.
habitat: Deserts and arid regions of North Africa, the Middle East, and Central Asia.
diet: Herbivore (desert vegetation, including thorny plants)
interesting_fact: A camel can drink up to 100 liters (26 gallons) of water in just 10-15 minutes.

name: Capybara
fun_facts: Capybaras are the largest rodents in the world, native to South America.
They are semi-aquatic, spending much of their time in water, where they can hold their breath for up to 5 minutes.
Capybaras are highly social animals, living in groups of 10-20 individuals.
habitat: Dense forests, savannas, and wetlands near water bodies in South America.
diet: Herbivore (grasses, aquatic plants, fruits, bark)
average_lifespan_years: 8-10 in the wild, up to 12 in captivity
interesting_fact: Capybaras often allow birds to perch on their backs and eat insects from their fur, a symbiotic relationship.

name: Caribou
fun_facts: Caribou (known as reindeer in Eurasia) are deer species, notable because both male and female caribou grow antlers.
They are well-adapted to cold environments, with thick coats and large hooves that act like snowshoes.
Caribou undertake some of the longest terrestrial migrations of any mammal.
habitat: Tundra, boreal forests, and mountains in Arctic and sub-Arctic regions of North America, Europe, and Asia.
diet: Herbivore (lichen, mosses, sedges, grasses, leaves of shrubs)
average_lifespan_years: 15-20 in the wild
interesting_fact: Caribou hooves change shape seasonally; in winter, they become harder and sharper, providing better grip on ice and snow.

name: Cassowary
fun_facts: Cassowaries are large, flightless birds native to the tropical rainforests of New Guinea and northeastern Australia.
They are often considered the most dangerous birds in the world due to their powerful legs and dagger-like claws.
Cassowaries have a distinctive bony casque on their heads, which may protect them from falling fruit or aid in pushing through dense vegetation.
habitat: Tropical rainforests and woodlands of New Guinea and northeastern Australia.
diet: Omnivore (primarily fallen fruit, but also fungi, insects, small vertebrates)
average_lifespan_years: 40-50 in the wild
interesting_fact: Cassowaries play a crucial ecological role as seed dispersers for many rainforest trees, especially for large fruits that other animals cannot consume.

name: Caterpillar
fun_facts: Caterpillars are the larval stage of butterflies and moths.
They are voracious eaters, primarily consuming leaves, to grow rapidly before pupating.
Many caterpillars have fascinating defense mechanisms, including camouflage, bright warning colors, and irritating hairs.
habitat: Found in almost every terrestrial habitat where their host plants grow, globally.
diet: Herbivore (primarily leaves of specific host plants, sometimes flowers or fruits)
average_lifespan_years: Weeks to a few months (larval stage)
interesting_fact: Some caterpillars can produce silk, which they use to build shelters, climb, or spin cocoons for pupation.

name: Chameleon
fun_facts: Chameleons are lizards famous for their ability to change color, not just for camouflage but also for communication and thermoregulation.
They have independently moving eyes, allowing them to look in two different directions at once.
Chameleons possess a long, sticky tongue that can be twice the length of their body, which they use to rapidly catch prey.
habitat: Forests, rainforests, savannas, and semi-deserts, primarily in Africa and Madagascar.
diet: Carnivore (insects, small lizards, birds)
average_lifespan_years: 2-10 depending on species
interesting_fact: Chameleons' toes are arranged in groups of two and three, forming pincer-like claws that provide a strong grip on branches.

name: Crab
fun_facts: Crabs are crustaceans with a thick exoskeleton, a single pair of claws, and typically a very short, tucked-under tail.
They walk sideways, which is a distinctive characteristic.
Crabs are omnivores and scavengers, playing an important role in cleaning up their ecosystems.
habitat: Diverse marine, freshwater, and terrestrial environments worldwide, from deep ocean trenches to tropical beaches.
diet: Omnivore (algae, mollusks, worms, crustaceans, fungi, bacteria, detritus)
average_lifespan_years: 3-10, some species up to 100 (e.g., Japanese spider crab)
interesting_fact: The largest known crab species is the Japanese spider crab, which can have a leg span of up to 3.7 meters (12 feet).

name: Deer
fun_facts: Deer are ruminant mammals forming the family Cervidae, characterized by the presence of antlers in most males (and female reindeer).
Antlers are bony growths that are shed and regrown annually, unlike horns which are permanent.
Deer have an excellent sense of smell and hearing, crucial for detecting predators.
habitat: Forests, grasslands, wetlands, and tundra across most continents, except Australia and Antarctica.
diet: Herbivore (leaves, twigs, bark, buds, shoots, grasses, forbs)
average_lifespan_years: 5-15 in the wild, depending on species and region
interesting_fact: White-tailed deer can run at speeds up to 48 km/h (30 mph) and jump obstacles over 2.7 meters (9 feet) high.

name: Dog
fun_facts: Dogs are domesticated mammals, descended from wolves, and are known for their loyalty and companionship to humans.
They have an exceptional sense of smell, estimated to be 10,000 to 100,000 times more acute than humans'.
Dogs communicate through a variety of barks, growls, whines, and body language.
habitat: Domesticated worldwide; feral dogs can be found in various environments.
diet: Omnivore (depends on diet provided by humans or scavenging)
predators: Humans (often in cases of abuse or culling)
Larger predators in wild settings (e.g., wolves, bears)
prey: Variable, based on diet provided or opportunistic scavenging
average_lifespan_years: 10-13, varies greatly by breed and size
interesting_fact: The oldest known dog breed is the Basenji, originating from Central Africa.

name: Duck
fun_facts: Ducks are waterfowl known for their webbed feet, which are ideal for swimming.
Many duck species are migratory, traveling long distances between breeding and wintering grounds.
Ducks have waterproof feathers due to a special oil they spread over their plumage.
habitat: Freshwater and saltwater environments worldwide, including ponds, lakes, rivers, and coastal areas.
diet: Omnivore (aquatic plants, seeds, insects, worms, small crustaceans, fish)
average_lifespan_years: 5-10 in the wild, up to 20 in captivity
interesting_fact: The male duck's (drake's) reproductive organ can be extraordinarily long and corkscrew-shaped in some species.

name: Eagle
fun_facts: Eagles are large, powerful birds of prey with heavy heads and beaks and strong, muscular legs.
They have exceptional eyesight, allowing them to spot prey from very high altitudes.
Eagles build large nests, called eyries, often in tall trees or on cliffs.
habitat: Diverse habitats including mountains, forests, coastlines, and open plains across most continents.
diet: Carnivore (fish, small mammals, other birds, reptiles, carrion)
predators: Larger predators may occasionally target young eagles or eggs
average_lifespan_years: 20-30 in the wild, up to 50 in captivity
interesting_fact: The Golden Eagle is one of the most widespread eagle species, found in the Northern Hemisphere.

name: Falcon
fun_facts: Falcons are birds of prey known for their incredible speed and agility in flight.
The peregrine falcon is the fastest bird in the world, capable of diving at speeds over 320 km/h (200 mph).
They have a distinctive 'tomial tooth' or notch on their beak, which they use to sever the spine of their prey.
habitat: Various habitats from open country, coastlines, and mountains to urban areas, found worldwide.
diet: Carnivore (primarily birds, but also small mammals and insects)
average_lifespan_years: 10-15 in the wild, up to 20 in captivity
interesting_fact: Peregrine falcons have specialized nostrils that allow them to breathe efficiently during their high-speed dives by managing air pressure.

name: Ferret
fun_facts: Ferrets are domesticated polecats, slender, carnivorous mammals belonging to the weasel family.
They are known for their playful and curious nature, and for sleeping up to 75% of the day.
Ferrets have a distinctive musky odor due to scent glands, which can be expressed when startled.
habitat: Domesticated worldwide; wild polecats inhabit forests, grasslands, and farmlands in Eurasia and North Africa.
diet: Carnivore (small rodents, rabbits, birds, insects)
average_lifespan_years: 5-10 in captivity
interesting_fact: The practice of 'ferreting' involves using ferrets to flush out rabbits from burrows for hunting.

name: Flamingo
fun_facts: Flamingos are wading birds known for their striking pink or reddish plumage, long legs, and S-shaped necks.
Their distinctive color comes from carotenoid pigments in the food they eat (algae, brine shrimp).
Flamingos filter-feed by holding their beaks upside down in the water, sieving out small organisms.
habitat: Shallow lagoons, lakes, and estuaries in tropical and subtropical regions worldwide.
diet: Omnivore (algae, brine shrimp, small insects, larvae)
predators: Birds of prey (prey on eggs and chicks)
average_lifespan_years: 20-30 in the wild, up to 50 in captivity
interesting_fact: Flamingos often stand on one leg, a behavior thought to conserve body heat or reduce muscle fatigue.

name: Frog
fun_facts: Frogs are amphibians known for their smooth, moist skin, long powerful legs adapted for jumping, and bulging eyes.
Many species of frogs undergo metamorphosis from aquatic tadpoles to terrestrial adults.
Frogs use a variety of calls to attract mates, defend territory, and communicate with other frogs.
habitat: Diverse habitats from rainforests and wetlands to deserts, usually near water sources, globally.
diet: Carnivore (insects, spiders, slugs, worms, small fish)
average_lifespan_years: 3-10 in the wild, some species up to 20 in captivity
interesting_fact: The largest frog in the world is the Goliath frog of West Africa, which can grow over 30 cm (1 foot) long and weigh more than 3 kg (7 pounds).

name: Gazelle
fun_facts: Gazelles are agile antelopes known for their speed and ability to make sudden turns, allowing them to escape predators.
Many species can run at sustained speeds of 60-80 km/h (37-50 mph) and sprint up to 97 km/h (60 mph).
They have slender bodies, long legs, and often distinct facial markings.
habitat: Grasslands, savannas, and deserts of Africa and Asia.
diet: Herbivore (grasses, leaves, shoots, herbs)
average_lifespan_years: 10-12 in the wild
interesting_fact: Thomson's gazelle is known for 'stotting,' a behavior where it leaps high into the air with all four feet off the ground, often to signal to a predator that it has been spotted.

name: Goat
fun_facts: Goats are domesticated ruminant mammals known for their hardiness and ability to graze on a wide variety of vegetation.
They have distinctive rectangular pupils, which give them a wide field of vision.
Goats are very agile and excellent climbers, often found on steep slopes and rocky terrain.
habitat: Domesticated worldwide; wild goats inhabit mountainous and rocky regions.
diet: Herbivore (grasses, leaves, shrubs, thorny bushes)
interesting_fact: Goats are one of the first animals to be domesticated by humans, around 10,000 years ago.

name: Goose
fun_facts: Geese are large waterfowl known for their strong family bonds and aggressive territorial behavior.
They are highly migratory, often flying in V-formations, which helps conserve energy.
Geese are primarily herbivorous, grazing on grasses and aquatic plants.
habitat: Found near water bodies like lakes, ponds, rivers, and marshes across most continents.
diet: Herbivore (grasses, grains, aquatic plants, roots)
average_lifespan_years: 10-24 in the wild, up to 30 in captivity
interesting_fact: Some geese pairs mate for life and are known to mourn the loss of a partner.

name: Guinea Pig
fun_facts: Guinea pigs are small, tailless rodents native to South America, commonly kept as pets.
They are social animals and prefer to live in groups.
Guinea pigs cannot synthesize their own Vitamin C and require it from their diet, similar to humans.
habitat: Domesticated worldwide; wild ancestors lived in grassy plains and rocky areas of South America.
diet: Herbivore (hay, fresh vegetables, commercial pellets)
interesting_fact: Despite their name, guinea pigs are not from Guinea and are not pigs; their name might come from the 'squeal' sound they make.

name: Hamster
fun_facts: Hamsters are rodents known for their short tails, stumpy legs, and large cheek pouches used to carry food.
They are typically nocturnal, meaning they are most active at night.
Hamsters hoard food in their burrows, a behavior essential for survival in the wild.
habitat: Domesticated worldwide; wild hamsters inhabit steppes, sand dunes, and arid regions of Eurasia.
diet: Omnivore (seeds, nuts, grains, fruits, vegetables, insects)
interesting_fact: The name 'hamster' comes from the German word 'hamstern,' which means 'to hoard.'

name: Hawk
fun_facts: Hawks are medium-sized diurnal birds of prey, known for their sharp talons, hooked beaks, and keen eyesight.
They are powerful hunters, often employing a 'perch-and-pounce' hunting strategy.
Many hawk species exhibit sexual dimorphism, with females typically larger than males.
habitat: Diverse habitats including forests, grasslands, deserts, mountains, and urban areas worldwide.
diet: Carnivore (small mammals, birds, reptiles, amphibians, insects)
average_lifespan_years: 10-20 in the wild, up to 30 in captivity
interesting_fact: The Red-tailed Hawk is one of the most common and widespread hawk species in North America.

name: Hedgehog
fun_facts: Hedgehogs are small, spiny mammals native to Europe, Asia, and Africa, known for rolling into a ball for defense.
Their spines are modified hairs, stiffened with keratin, and are not barbed like porcupine quills.
Hedgehogs are primarily nocturnal and have a good sense of smell and hearing to find prey.
habitat: Woodlands, grasslands, hedgerows, suburban gardens, and parks.
diet: Omnivore (insects, worms, slugs, snails, small vertebrates, fruits, fungi)
average_lifespan_years: 2-5 in the wild, up to 10 in captivity
interesting_fact: Hedgehogs engage in a behavior called 'self-anointing,' where they spread foamy saliva over their spines after encountering a new scent, though its purpose is not fully understood.

name: Hyena
fun_facts: Hyenas are carnivorous mammals known for their dog-like appearance, powerful jaws, and distinctive 'laughing' calls.
Despite their appearance, they are more closely related to cats than to dogs.
Spotted hyenas live in large, complex social groups called clans, often dominated by females.
habitat: Grasslands, savannas, woodlands, and semi-deserts in Africa and parts of Asia.
diet: Carnivore (scavenged carcasses, but also active hunters of ungulates like wildebeest and zebra)
average_lifespan_years: 12-15 in the wild, up to 25 in captivity
interesting_fact: Hyenas have incredibly strong jaws and teeth, capable of crushing bones to access marrow, making them efficient scavengers.

name: Iguana
fun_facts: Iguanas are large, herbivorous lizards native to tropical and subtropical regions of the Americas.
They are excellent climbers and swimmers, often found near water.
Iguanas have a parietal eye (or third eye) on top of their heads that detects changes in light, helping them detect predators from above.
habitat: Rainforests, dry forests, coastal areas, and islands in Central and South America and the Caribbean.
diet: Herbivore (leaves, flowers, fruits)
average_lifespan_years: 15-20 in the wild, up to 25 in captivity
interesting_fact: Green iguanas can detach their tails (autotomy) when threatened, which then wiggles to distract the predator while the iguana escapes.

name: Jackal
fun_facts: Jackals are medium-sized canids native to Africa, Asia, and Southeast Europe, known for their opportunistic feeding habits.
They are highly adaptable and can thrive in various environments.
Jackals are primarily nocturnal or crepuscular, hunting alone or in pairs.
habitat: Savannas, grasslands, deserts, scrublands, and open woodlands.
diet: Omnivore (small mammals, birds, reptiles, insects, fruit, carrion)
average_lifespan_years: 8-10 in the wild, up to 16 in captivity
interesting_fact: Jackals are monogamous, with pairs often maintaining territories and raising their young together.

name: Jaguar
fun_facts: Jaguars are the largest big cats in the Americas and are known for their powerful bite, capable of crushing turtle shells.
Their rosettes (spots) are more complex than a leopard's, with small spots inside the larger ones.
Jaguars are excellent swimmers and often hunt in water, preying on fish, caimans, and anacondas.
habitat: Rainforests, wetlands, and open woodlands in Central and South America.
diet: Carnivore (large and medium-sized mammals like capybaras, peccaries, deer, and reptiles, fish)
average_lifespan_years: 12-15 in the wild, up to 20 in captivity
interesting_fact: The jaguar is often considered a keystone species in its ecosystem, as its predatory role helps maintain the health of prey populations.

name: Jellyfish
fun_facts: Jellyfish are free-swimming marine animals with umbrella-shaped bells and trailing tentacles.
They are not actually fish, but invertebrates, and have no brain, heart, bones, or eyes (though some have light-sensing organs).
Jellyfish use stinging cells called nematocysts on their tentacles to capture prey and defend themselves.
habitat: All oceans, from surface waters to the deep sea, and some freshwater lakes.
diet: Carnivore (zooplankton, small fish, eggs, other jellyfish)
average_lifespan_years: Few weeks to a few months, some deep-sea species much longer (up to 30 years for some)
interesting_fact: The 'immortal jellyfish' (Turritopsis dohrnii) is capable of reverting to its juvenile polyp stage after reaching sexual maturity, theoretically making it biologically immortal.

name: Lizard
fun_facts: Lizards are a widespread group of squamate reptiles, with over 6,000 species.
Many lizards can detach their tails (autotomy) as a defense mechanism, which can later regrow.
They have excellent vision and some species, like geckos, have highly specialized toe pads for climbing.
habitat: Extremely diverse, from deserts and rainforests to mountains and urban areas, found on all continents except Antarctica.
diet: Varies by species (insects, small mammals, other reptiles, eggs, plants, fruits)
average_lifespan_years: 2-20, depending on species (some large monitor lizards live longer)
interesting_fact: The Komodo dragon is the largest living species of lizard, growing up to 3 meters (10 feet) in length.

name: Mole
fun_facts: Moles are small, burrowing mammals adapted to a subterranean lifestyle.
They have small eyes and poor eyesight, but excellent senses of touch and smell, especially with their star-nosed noses.
Moles create extensive networks of tunnels, which they use to hunt for invertebrates.
habitat: Forests, grasslands, and agricultural fields in North America, Europe, and Asia.
diet: Carnivore (earthworms, insect larvae, other invertebrates)
interesting_fact: Moles have extra thumbs (sesamoid bones) on their front paws, which help them dig more efficiently.

name: Mongoose
fun_facts: Mongooses are small, carnivorous mammals native to Africa, Asia, and Southern Europe.
They are well-known for their ability to fight and kill venomous snakes, thanks to their speed, agility, and some level of immunity to snake venom.
Many species are diurnal and highly social, living in groups.
habitat: Forests, savannas, grasslands, and arid regions.
diet: Carnivore (insects, crustaceans, worms, reptiles, birds, small mammals, eggs, fruit)
average_lifespan_years: 6-10 in the wild, up to 20 in captivity
interesting_fact: The meerkat is a type of mongoose known for its upright sentinel behavior.

name: Octopus
fun_facts: Octopuses are cephalopod mollusks, known for their eight arms, soft bodies, and remarkable intelligence.
They have three hearts: two pump blood through the gills, and one circulates blood to the rest of the body.
Octopuses can change the color and texture of their skin almost instantly for camouflage or communication.
habitat: All oceans, from coastal waters to the deep sea.
diet: Carnivore (crabs, lobsters, fish, small mollusks)
average_lifespan_years: 1-3, some species up to 5
interesting_fact: Octopuses have highly complex nervous systems, with two-thirds of their neurons located in their arms, allowing them to 'taste' and manipulate objects independently.

name: Parrot
fun_facts: Parrots are birds characterized by a strong, curved beak, upright stance, and zygodactyl feet (two toes pointing forward, two backward).
Many species are known for their ability to mimic human speech and other sounds.
Parrots are highly intelligent and often form strong social bonds.
habitat: Tropical and subtropical regions worldwide, especially in South America, Australia, and Africa.
diet: Herbivore (seeds, nuts, fruits, buds, nectar, sometimes insects)
average_lifespan_years: 10-80+, depending on species
interesting_fact: Some large parrot species, like the macaw, can live for 60-80 years or more.

name: Peacock
fun_facts: Peacocks are male peafowl, famous for their iridescent tail feathers (trains), which can reach over 1.5 meters (5 feet) long.
The magnificent display of their train is used to attract mates.
Peafowl are ground-dwelling birds, capable of short flights.
habitat: Forests and woodlands, particularly near water, native to India, Sri Lanka, and Southeast Asia.
diet: Omnivore (seeds, insects, fruits, small reptiles, amphibians)
average_lifespan_years: 10-20 in the wild, up to 25 in captivity
interesting_fact: Despite their large train, peafowl can fly, though usually only for short distances and low to the ground, often into trees for roosting.

name: Pelican
fun_facts: Pelicans are large water birds characterized by a distinctive pouch under their beak, which they use to scoop up fish.
They are highly social birds, often fishing and nesting in colonies.
Some pelican species dive for fish, while others forage by swimming on the surface.
habitat: Coastal areas, estuaries, lakes, and rivers on all continents except Antarctica.
diet: Carnivore (primarily fish, but also amphibians, crustaceans, and occasionally other birds)
predators: Sharks (prey on young or vulnerable adults)
average_lifespan_years: 10-25 in the wild, up to 30 in captivity
interesting_fact: The Australian Pelican has the longest bill of any bird, reaching up to 49 cm (19.5 inches).

name: Pigeon
fun_facts: Pigeons (doves) are birds known for their cooing sounds and ability to fly at high speeds.
The Rock Dove, or common city pigeon, has been domesticated for thousands of years.
Pigeons have an extraordinary homing instinct, capable of finding their way back to their loft from hundreds of miles away.
habitat: Ubiquitous in urban and suburban areas worldwide, also found in cliffs and rocky habitats.
diet: Omnivore (seeds, grains, fruits, insects, human food scraps)
average_lifespan_years: 3-5 in the wild, up to 15 in captivity
interesting_fact: Pigeons were extensively used for carrying messages throughout history, especially during wartime.

name: Rabbit
fun_facts: Rabbits are small mammals known for their long ears, bushy tails, and powerful hind legs adapted for jumping.
They are herbivores and re-ingest their own soft fecal pellets (cecotropes) to extract more nutrients.
Rabbits are highly social animals, living in groups in underground burrows called warrens.
habitat: Grasslands, woodlands, forests, deserts, and wetlands across most continents.
diet: Herbivore (grasses, clover, leafy weeds, some vegetables)
average_lifespan_years: 1-3 in the wild, up to 10 in captivity
interesting_fact: Rabbits can see almost 360 degrees, with only a small blind spot directly in front of their nose.

name: Raven
fun_facts: Ravens are large, all-black passerine birds, known for their intelligence and problem-solving abilities.
They are highly vocal, producing a wide range of calls, and can mimic sounds from their environment.
Ravens often mate for life and are known to fly in impressive aerial displays.
habitat: Forests, mountains, coasts, and deserts across the Northern Hemisphere.
diet: Omnivore (carrion, small animals, birds, eggs, insects, grains, fruits)
average_lifespan_years: 10-15 in the wild, up to 40 in captivity
interesting_fact: Ravens are known to engage in 'anting,' where they allow ants to crawl on their feathers, possibly to remove parasites or provide preening assistance.

name: Rooster
fun_facts: A rooster is an adult male chicken, known for its loud 'cock-a-doodle-doo' crow, typically at dawn.
They often act as protectors of the flock, warning hens of danger.
Roosters have distinctive combs and wattles, which are fleshy growths on their heads and under their chins.
habitat: Domesticated worldwide; wild ancestors (Red Junglefowl) live in forests of Southeast Asia.
diet: Omnivore (grains, seeds, insects, worms, small vertebrates, greens)
average_lifespan_years: 5-8 in captivity
interesting_fact: The crow of a rooster is one of the loudest animal sounds, reaching over 100 decibels.

name: Salmon
fun_facts: Salmon are ray-finned fish known for their incredible migratory journeys, often returning to their natal streams to spawn.
They undergo dramatic physiological changes as they transition from saltwater to freshwater for spawning.
Salmon are a keystone species in many ecosystems, providing food for a wide range of predators and nutrients for riverine environments.
habitat: Temperate waters of the North Atlantic and Pacific Oceans; migrate to freshwater rivers and streams to spawn.
diet: Carnivore (insects and small crustaceans in freshwater; smaller fish, squid, and krill in saltwater)
average_lifespan_years: 2-7, depending on species
interesting_fact: Pacific salmon species typically die after spawning, while Atlantic salmon can return to the ocean and spawn multiple times.
